texts.shortText:
Medium- to large cuttlefish with a broad, finely papillose mantle, its frontal margin produced into a wide bulge mid-dorsally. Also capable of erecting several large knobbly papillae around the eyes and on the mantle, as additional camouflage or when in threat posture. Narrow fins run along entire lateral margins and are well separated at the tail. Arms short, with four rows of suckers. Tentacle clubs elongate and narrow with numerous small, equal-sized suckers. Cuttlebone broadly oval with a pointed knob at posterior end.

Colour variable and individuals can change their appearance within seconds: red-purple, orange-brown or yellow, or even completely white are possible background colours. A typical colouration is mottled pinkish-brown dorsally with yellow to orange fins, a pinkish-white underside, and sometimes dark longitudinal stripes along the arms. Sometimes threatens with large and deeply black eye-spots on either side of the second half of the mantle.

Global: Probably endemic to South Africa, but some accounts also list South West Indian Ocean.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.

Little is known about this species from the literature as it seems to have been confused by scientists and divers with S. vermiculata (see remarks in similar species below). Change colours within seconds using chromatophores, which as highly specialised pigment-containing skin cells that contract or relax in order to reveal or hide a specific colour tone on the skin.

Common along the south coast and from shallow water to depths of at least 100 m. It appears that this is the common large Sepia species in the kelp forests of False Bay.

Occupies narrow caves and rock overhangs where it rests during the day and is more active at night. Often seen resting together and in close proximity with Pyjama catsharks.
Details unknown, but all cuttlefish are predatory, shooting out the elongate tentacles to grasp prey and then tearing this apart with the beak.

Lay large, roundly pointed eggs which are attached underneath rocky overhangs and caves. Colour of eggs variable and range from see-through pale to deep black. Colour variation due to the fact that cuttlefish can coat their eggs in a layer of black ink, likely as both a form of camouflage and protection. Although adults are sometimes still observed around their clutches of eggs, there is no proven parental care.

As the young develop the ink layer peels off, making it possible for the unhatched animals to observe their environment from the safety of the egg, before they hatch as perfectly developed tiny cuttlefish. Development probably takes several months and certainly depends on water temperature. The young of this species are never seen in shallow waters either because they have a highly cryptic lifestyle and hide in rock crevices or algae, or they spend the first months in deeper waters.

There has been considerable confusion in local and online field guides around the correct image identifications of local cuttlefish species, due to the fact that colouration, shape and posture are highly variable and that cephalopods can change their appearance within seconds. After the cuttlebone, which lies inside the animal and which is hence not useful to identify live specimens, one of the main identification characters are the tentacle clubs. However, these are the animals most important weapon and tool for catching prey, and are hence held safely and invisible in between the arms.

Treating our species identification with some caution, the Simonâ€™s Town cuttlefish is the main and most common large cuttlefish in the shallow water kelp forest. The second common species, the Tuberculate cuttlefish Sepia tuberculata, is much smaller and fairly easily distinguished by the smaller size, the rough tuberculate surface, and perhaps most easily by the unusual behaviour of physically attaching to the substrate using the large glandular patch on the underside. Especially small specimens of S. simoniana can look similar to S. tuberculata but are able to show larger eye-spots as threat display (see images of juvenile).

Sepia simoniana is very similar in size and form to the slightly larger Patchwork cuttlefish S. vermiculata, the only species in the Western Cape that is known to enter estuaries and which is common in the Knysna Lagoon, as well as reported from Langebaan. In that species however the mantle is broader, the surface smoother, and the lateral fins broader. Colour displays are different in that it can show zebra-like, transverse patterns on the mantle, white spots on the base of the lateral fins and a narrow white line on the fin margin, which all seem to be characteristic. The cuttlebone of S. simoniana has a blunt knob on the posterior end rather than a sharp spine as in S. vermiculata.

Another species, identified in this guide with caution as the Southern cuttlefish, Decorisepia australis, has a similar colour tone and general appearance to S. simoniana. In the field it can be identified by being marginally smaller than S. simoniana and by having slightly different body proportions that include shorter arms, a larger eye, and a slightly more elongated mantle. At first glance the colour pattern seem almost identical, however, D. australis has a deeper red colouration including a pinkish red belly. The best live identification character appears to be the presence of iridescent skin beneath the eye and underneath the front of the fin.

A further species of similar size to S. simoniana and S. vermiculata that is so far not covered in this guide and potentially hidden in images presented, Spathidosepion papillatum, occurs in the same waters and has enlarged suckers on the tentacle club.
